text: Modulation of E2F complexes during G0 to S phase transition in human primary B-lymphocytes .
The pocket protein - E2F complexes are convergence points for cell cycle signaling .
In the present report , we identified and monitored the pocket protein - E2F complexes in human primary B-lymphocytes after activation by phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate .

Consistent with previous data from human and mouse fibroblasts and T-lymphocytes , <extra_id_0> E2F4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> DP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> form the predominant E2F heterodimers both in G0 and G1 phases of the human B-lymphocyte cell cycle , whereas <extra_id_0> E2F1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> -3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> are first detected in late G1 , and their expression levels increase towards S phase .

Intriguingly , the major E2F complex that we detected in quiescent human B-lymphocytes is consisted of <extra_id_0> pRB <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> E2F4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and <extra_id_0> DP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

Though the levels of <extra_id_0> DP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> -2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> increase when cells progress from G0 to S , the proportion of <extra_id_0> DP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> to <extra_id_0> DP2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> remains relatively constant during the cell cycle .

We also observed an increase in electrophoretic mobility of the predominant E2F components , <extra_id_0> DP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> E2F4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , as B-lymphocytes progressed from G0 into early G1 .
This increase in mobility was attributable to dephosphorylation , as lambda phosphatase treatment could convert the slower migrating forms into the corresponding faster mobility forms .
We further demonstrated that this change in phosphorylation status correlates with a decrease in DNA binding activity .

This modulation of DNA binding activity mediated through the dephosphorylation of <extra_id_0> DP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> E2F4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> could help to explain the lack of in vivo DNA footprinting in late G1 and S phases of gene promoters negatively regulated through E2F sites and suggests a novel mechanism for controlling E2F transcriptional activity during the transition from quiescence to proliferation .
